reviews.text: Babylon’s Fall is a dull and cynical service game
the visual style that’s incredibly unappealing
mission structure that is somehow both dreadfully short and tedious
filling your screen with as many opportunities to micro-transact as it can, despite the fact it actually costs $60 to purchase
Babylon’s Fall’s low detail look is supposed to evoke a moving oil painting, but in practice, it’s not been implemented well at all
the game’s sludgy, low-quality characters look like you’ve zoomed in on the crowd of a PS2 racing game
PlatinumGames is renowned for its excellent combat systems... Babylon’s systems prove so mediocre
Enemies have way, way too much health. This doesn’t make them hard... it just means that you’re slapping away at them endlessly
DualSense integration is so weirdly aggressive that after a few missions we had to take a break because our hands were straining
terrible mission structure... locked in combat rooms over and over
any loot you find in these missions can’t be equiped or even looked at during missions... destroys any sense of flow
one of the more offensive championing of in-game purchases we’ve seen in a full-price game
the $60 price tag being first in line [for overhaul needs]
visually dated, consistently dull and features the most average PlatinumGames combat we can remember
the downtime between the dreadfully short and uninspiring missions
Combat can be fun in short bursts
a soulless, cynical game that you should avoid
